baseline_groups.claim_summary: A+ restaurants (top-half quality within A grade) are significantly more likely to voluntarily disclose their hygiene grade compared to lower-graded restaurants (CD-), consistent with signaling theory.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline replicates approximately Table 4, Column 2. Treatment is the A+ indicator (half_grade_def1_d1) with CD- as the omitted category. The coefficient represents the difference in disclosure probability between A+ and CD- restaurants. The paper also claims countersignaling (A+ restaurants with alternative quality signals disclose less), but the main estimand for the specification search is the A+ disclosure premium relative to CD-.

global_notes: 67 specifications with one clear baseline. Several heterogeneity specifications report interaction term coefficients rather than the main A+ coefficient, meaning they test the countersignaling hypothesis rather than providing a robustness check of the main signaling claim. The within-A-grade sample restriction (spec robust/sample/isA_pred1) changes the comparison group from CD- to A-, yielding a negative coefficient that represents a conceptually different estimand. Some functional form specs use a continuous treatment (num_grading) rather than the binary half-grade indicator, changing the treatment concept. Two alternative treatment specs (top_half_A, A_tercile_1) use different definitions of treatment but test a related hypothesis about within-grade quality and disclosure.
